# Definition

- an objective test consisting of two sets of items to be matched with each other for a specified attribute

--

- measures ability to identify relationship between a set of similar items

--

- recognition type and structured-response

--

- considered as modified multiple choice
---
# Parts of a Matching Type Test

Premises column is where the match **is located**

Responses column is where to **choose** a match
--
.pull-left[
### Column A (Premises)

1. Psychodynamic Theory

2. Trait Theory

3. Behaviorism

4. Humanism

]
--
.pull-right[
### Column B (Responses)

A. Sigmund Freud

B. Gordon Allport

C. B.F. Skinner

D. Carl Rogers
]
---
# Types of Matches
**Perfect Match** is when the number of items in premises and responses is **equal**

**Imperfect Match** is when the premises column **has less** items than premises column

--

.pull-left[
### Perfect Match
.pull-left[
1. Psychodynamic Theory

2. Trait Theory

3. Behaviorism

4. Humanism
]
.pull-right[
A. Sigmund Freud

B. Gordon Allport

C. B.F. Skinner

D. Carl Rogers
]
]

--

.pull-right[
### Imperfect Match
.pull-left[

3. Behaviorism

4. Humanism
]
.pull-right[
A. Sigmund Freud

B. Gordon Allport

C. B.F. Skinner

]

# Guidelines to Construction

1. Match the questions to your objectives

--

2. Give clear instructions

--

3. Use numbers for column A, capital letters for column B

--

4. Use imperfect match

--

5. Arrange column B in logical order

--

6. Put more words in column A

--

7. Keep two sets homogenous

--

8. Avoid using pattern

--

9. Avoid copying statements from textbooks
---

### Advantages
- Validity and reliablity is higher than essays

- Covers more content

- Provide objective measurement of student knowledge

- Easy to check

- Allows comparison of related ideas

- Scoring is not subjective

- Saves time in answering questions

- Limits the assessment to lower levels of understanding

- Measures factual knowledge only

- Students can guess in this type of exam

- There are certain subjects that objective examinations do not work

- Encourage cheating

- Requires more preparation for teachers

- Does not express the ideas of your students
